test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-1

test-case.description: A function cannot be declared in the 'http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema' namespace.

test-case.description: Arguments in functions cannot have default values initialized with '='(or in any other way).

test-case.description: Arguments in functions cannot have default values initialized with '='(or in any other way).

test-case.description: Arguments in functions cannot have default values initialized with ':='(or in any other way).

test-case.description: A user function whose return type doesn't match the body, which can be statically inferred.

test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-16
test-case.description: When declaring a function, the paranteses must be present even though it doesn't have any arguments.

test-case.description: When declaring a function, the paranteses must be present even though it doesn't have any arguments.

test-case.description: Two user functions using global variables.

test-case.description: User functions where the last argument of three arguments is unused.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-25
test-case.description: A function and a variable can have the same name.

test-case.description: A function declaration duplicated.

test-case.description: A function declaration duplicated; difference in return types is insignificant.

test-case.description: Overloading user functions based on arity.

test-case.description: One cannot declare a user function as xs:gYear.

test-case.description: A type error inside a function.

test-case.description: A call to a user declared function which almost is spelled correctly(#2).

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-36
test-case.description: The variable '$myArg' is in scope inside the function, but not in the query body.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-37
test-case.description: The variable '$myArg' is in scope inside one function, but not the other function.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-38
test-case.description: The variable '$myArg2' is in scope inside one function, but not the other function.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-39
test-case.description: Function arguments shadows global variables.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-40
test-case.description: Variables declared inside functions shadow function arguments.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-41
test-case.description: Type error in body of user function caused by the argument value.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-42
test-case.description: Type error(cardinality) in return value of user function caused by the argument value.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich

test-case.description: Item type error in argument value.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-44
test-case.description: Cardinality error in argument value.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-45
test-case.description: Item type error in argument value. xs:decimal doesn't match xs:integer.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-46
test-case.description: '1' doesn't match the empty-sequence().

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-47
test-case.description: 'empty-sequence()+' is syntactically invalid.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-48
test-case.description: 'empty-sequence()? is syntactically invalid.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-49
test-case.description: It is valid to declare an argument to be of type empty-sequence().

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-50
test-case.description: empty-sequence() as return type, but body doesn't match when run.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-51
test-case.description: Too few arguments passed to a user function.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-52
test-case.description: empty-sequence() as return type, and a body containing fn:error().

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-53
test-case.description: A global variable referenced from inside a function.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich

test-case.description: A more realistic case involving fn:error().

test-case.description: A more realistic case involving fn:error(), #2.

test-case.description: A more realistic case involving fn:error(), #3.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-57
test-case.description: The type 'none' isn't available to users.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-58
test-case.description: The type 'none()' isn't available to users.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-59
test-case.description: A call to a user function where the argument in the callsite corresponding to an unused argument contains a type error.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-60
test-case.description: An argument in a user function is not in scope in the query body.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-61
test-case.description: An argument in a user function is not in scope in the query body.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-62
test-case.description: Check that a global variable is in scope despite an unused function being declared.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-63
test-case.description: A function call that could be a call to a hypotehical user function.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-64
test-case.description: A function call that could be a call to a hypothetical user function(#2).

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-65
test-case.description: Since the return type is empty-sequence() it is a type error(XPTY0004) to pass its return value to anything which requires cardinality exactly-one. That the function's body is of type 'none', doesn't affect that, it only adapts to the declared return type. However, there's no constraints on what is reported first, so FOER0000 can also be issued.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-66
test-case.description: If static typing is in use, XPTY004 is issued since local:myFunction() has static type item()*. However, if the function is invoked FOER0000 is issued.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-67
test-case.description: A function call that reminds of the range expression.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K-FunctionProlog-68
test-case.description: A call to a user function where the argument in the callsite corresponding to a used argument contains a type error.

test-case.description: Call a function that subsequently calls a recursive function.

test-case.description: A call site that has an operand that gets treated as an xs:integer.

test-case.description: Pass a sequence of mixed atomic values and nodes to an argument which has no type declared.

test-case.description: Pass a value which cannot be converted to the expected type.

test-case.description: Mix in an atomic value which doesn't match the type it's being converted to.

test-case.Creator: Frans Englich
test-case.name: K2-FunctionProlog-34
test-case.description: Call fn:true() and fn:false() and pass to a user function.

test-case.description: Call fn:true() and fn:false() and pass to a user function.

test-case.description: Call fn:true() and fn:false() and pass to a user function(different cardinality).

test-case.description: Mix in an atomic value which matches the type it's being converted to.

test-case.description: Trigger a crash in an implementation by having a user declared function with type, that has a text node constructor containing a call to a nonexisting function.

test-case.description: Use complex real-world case for function calls, with automatic conversion not needed.
